channel.title: Reuters: World News
channel.description: Reuters.com is your source for breaking news, business, financial and investing news, including personal finance and stocks. Reuters is the leading global provider of news, financial information and technology solutions to the world's media, financial institutions, businesses and individuals.
channel.copyright: All rights reserved. Users may download and print extracts of content from this website for their own personal and non-commercial use only. item.title: Backed by U.S. strikes, Iraq Kurds retake strategic dam - officials
item.description: BAGHDAD (Reuters) - Iraqi and Kurdish forces recaptured Iraq's biggest dam from Islamist militants with the help of U.S. air strikes to secure a vital strategic objective in fighting that threatens to break up the country, Kurdish and U.S. officials said on Monday.

item.title: Missouri governor lifts Ferguson curfew as National Guard called in
item.description: FERGUSON Mo. (Reuters) - Missouri Governor Jay Nixon lifted the curfew for the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson on Monday and began deploying National Guard troops to help quell days of rioting and looting spurred by the fatal shooting of a black unarmed teenager by a white policeman.

item.title: Chinese military's ability to wage war eroded by graft, its generals warn
item.description: BEIJING (Reuters) - As tensions spike between China and other countries in Asia's disputed waters, serving and retired Chinese military officers as well as state media are questioning whether China's armed forces are too corrupt to fight and win a war.

item.title: As Taliban push quickens, Afghan troops ordered: take no prisoners
item.description: KABUL (Reuters) - As U.S. forces withdraw from Afghanistan, the battlefield they leave behind is changing dramatically and becoming more deadly.

item.title: Israel, Palestinians say agree to extend Gaza truce by 24 hours
item.description: CAIRO/JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Israeli and Palestinian officials said on Monday they had agreed to extend a Gaza ceasefire by another 24 hours to allow time for the sides to continue negotiations for terms of a possible agreement.

item.title: Renegade Libyan general claims air strikes on Tripoli
item.description: TRIPOLI/BENGHAZI Libya (Reuters) - Renegade General Khalifa Haftar's air force was responsible for strikes on Islamist-leaning militia in Tripoli on Monday, one of his commanders said, after weeks of fighting for the capital in Libya's worst violence since Muammar Gaddafi was toppled in 2011.

item.title: Dozens killed in attack on convoy, Ukraine says; rebels deny firing rocket
item.description: KIEV (Reuters) - Dozens of people, including women and children, were killed fleeing fighting in eastern Ukraine on Monday when their convoy of buses was hit by rocket fire, military spokesmen said.

item.title: Pakistan's third largest party to quit parliament to force PM resignation
item.description: ISLAMABAD (Reuters) - Lawmakers from Pakistan's third largest party will resign from parliament to try to force Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to step down, a party official said on Monday.

item.title: Liberia hunts escaped Ebola victims as WHO calls for controls
item.description: MONROVIA/GENEVA (Reuters) - Liberia struggled on Monday to track down 17 suspected Ebola carriers who fled quarantine at the weekend, while the U.N. health agency urged affected West African nations to screen all departures in a bid to contain the worst outbreak of the virus.

item.title: Silva surges in Brazil election poll, runoff looks certain
item.description: BRASILIA (Reuters) - Marina Silva's entry into Brazil's presidential race will almost certainly force the October election into a second-round runoff and the environmentalist could even unseat President Dilma Rousseff, according to a poll released on Monday.

item.title: Syrian forces hit Islamic State in Raqqa, destroy water plant
item.description: BEIRUT (Reuters) - Syrian government forces struck Islamic State positions in and around the eastern Syrian city of Raqqa, residents said on Monday, part of a growing campaign against hardline militants who control a third of the country.

item.title: WikiLeaks' Assange hopes to exit London embassy if UK lets him
item.description: LONDON (Reuters) - WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, who has spent over two years in Ecuador's London embassy to avoid a sex crimes inquiry in Sweden, said on Monday he planned to leave the building "soon", but Britain signalled it would still arrest him if he tried.

item.title: Landmark Brazil poll contains good news for Rousseff
item.description: SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Although a new poll shows Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff suddenly facing a tougher road to re-election, she also saw a sharp recovery in her approval ratings and resilient voter support through what will likely be the campaign's most emotional and volatile period.

item.title: German spying report angers Turkey, embarrasses Berlin
item.description: BERLIN/ANKARA (Reuters) - The German government faced an angry reaction from Turkey and accusations of hypocrisy from its own opposition on Monday after media reports that its intelligence agency spied on its NATO ally.

item.title: IAEA head expects progress by deadline in Iran nuclear inquiry
item.description: VIENNA (Reuters) - The United Nations nuclear watchdog said on Monday Iran had begun implementing transparency measures ahead of an Aug 25 deadline, as part of a long-running investigation into suspected atomic bomb research by Tehran.

item.title: Crowd loots Ebola centre in Liberian capital, worker says patients removed
item.description: MONROVIA (Reuters) - A crowd attacked a makeshift Ebola quarantine centre in a rundown neighbourhood of the Liberian capital, throwing stones and looting equipment and food, witnesses said, and a health worker said patients had been removed from the building.

item.title: Pakistan protest leaders ignore or reject Sharif's talks offer
item.description: ISLAMABAD (Reuters) - Pakistani opposition leader Imran Khan and a firebrand cleric either ignored or rejected an offer of talks from Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Monday, the fourth day of anti-government protests in the capital.

item.title: Kuwait briefly detains Muslim cleric U.S. suspects of militant financing
item.description: KUWAIT (Reuters) - Kuwait briefly detained a prominent Sunni Muslim cleric less than two weeks after the United States included him on a sanctions list on suspicion he was funnelling money to militants in Iraq and Syria, his lawyer said on Monday.

item.title: As Gaza war subsides, a battle over how it is investigated
item.description: JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Even before starting work as chairman of a U.N. human rights commission investigating the Gaza war, Canadian law professor William Schabas has been vilified as an apologist for Iran incapable of setting aside his perceived anti-Israel bias.

item.title: Russian court jails opponents of Putin on rioting charges
item.description: MOSCOW (Reuters) - Four Russians detained during a protest against President Vladimir Putin were sentenced to prison terms on Monday after a trial critics say is part of a Kremlin campaign to stifle dissent while all eyes are on the Ukraine crisis.

item.title: Kurdish, Iraqi forces in control of Mosul dam - spokesman
item.description: BAGHDAD (Reuters) - Kurdish peshmerga fighters and Iraqi counter-terrorism forces have pushed Islamic State militants out of Mosul dam, state television reported on Monday.

item.title: Russia says agreement reached on aid to Ukraine but not on ceasefire
item.description: BERLIN (Reuters) - Russia on Monday said all objections to it sending a humanitarian convoy to Ukraine had been resolved but said no progress had been made in Berlin talks toward a ceasefire between government and rebel forces in the east of the country.

item.title: Japan suspect in Thai 'baby factory' scandal hands over DNA samples
item.description: BANGKOK (Reuters) - The lawyer of a Japanese man suspected of having fathered at least 12 babies using Thai surrogate mothers submitted DNA samples to Thai police on Monday in a bid to clear his name.

item.title: FBI assist Indonesian police in probe of American death
item.description: DENPASAR Indonesia (Reuters) - The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation is assisting Indonesian police in gathering evidence in the death of a Chicago-based woman whose body was found in a bloodied suitcase on the resort island of Bali, local police said on Monday.

item.title: Pope urges Korean reconciliation, reaches out to China
item.description: SEOUL (Reuters) - Pope Francis on Monday called for peace and reconciliation on the divided Korean peninsula and sent a further message of goodwill to China, wrapping-up a five day trip to South Korea and the first papal visit to Asia in 15 years.
